Sreyleak is a garment factory worker, while her husband is a security guard. She is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Dial's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members. Mrs. Dial is the group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the other members.

Mrs. Dial, a married woman, was born in 1975. She and her husband, Mr. Dang, are farmers who own a plot of land which they use to grow corn and rice. In order to support and improve this farming, Mrs. Dial would like to ask for a loan to buy gasoline to fuel her pump for growing rice.

This couple has three children: two are attending the local schools and the youngest one is 2 years old.

loans.use: To buy gasoline to fuel her pump for growing rice.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics, etc., for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is from the village of Centro Napu, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, married and has one adult child. To make a living, Jessica runs a business venture in the retail sector selling a variety of products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community.

Jessica has been engaged in her business for 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. Jessica joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Jessica is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP with which she will purchase additional inventory to add to her working capital. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Jessica from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase variety store products, household needs such as soap.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie S. is from the village of Poblacion, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 54 years old. Rosemarie is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Rosemarie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods,  shampoo, soap, rice per kilogram,  beverages, breads & toothpaste in the local community. Rosemarie has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosemarie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Rosemarie is requesting a new loan of 26,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods & a sack of rice. This will be the 20th loan taken out by Rosemarie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods & a sack of rice.

loans.name: Precentacion

texts.en:
Precentacion E. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Precentacion is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Precentacion owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, rice per kilogram, shampoo, soap, breads, biscuits & beverages in the local community. Precentacion has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Precentacion joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Precentacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Precentacion is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Precentacion from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & beverages.

loans.name: Marcelina's Group

texts.en:
Marcelina B. is from the village of Cutog GranD., Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Marcelina is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marcelina is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Marcelina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Marcelina has been engaged in her business for over 38 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP every three months.

In 2010, Marcelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This is the 3rd loan taken out by Marcelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Dolgor

texts.en:
Dolgor, 27, is married and lives with her husband and son in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her husband is a taxi driver who conducts his taxi service business while her son attends secondary school. They live in a ger, a Mongolian traditional housing tent, in someone else's backyard. 

Dolgor operates a clothing trading business in a rented booth in Huleg trading center, one of the busiest and most crowded markest in her area. After years of stable business operation she has been able to open one more booth at another trading center called Mon-Mandal. She is very hard-working lady who possesses good communication skills. She says, "I want to buy a place where I can build a winter shelter." She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to buy more clothes at wholesale prices and increase her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more clothes at wholesale prices.

loans.name: Menzita

texts.en:
Menzita D. T. is from the village of Poblacion, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Menzita is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Menzita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and raising pigs for sale. She is also making and selling cheese cup cakes. Menzita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Menzita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Menzita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. Menzita is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Menzita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Dugersuren

texts.en:
Dugersuren is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children, one son and two daughters, in their own house in Zavhan province, Mongolia. His wife is a salesperson in a private retail trading store. His twins, a boy and a girl, attend secondary school while the youngest child, age 3, goes to kindergarten. He operates a public transportation service between Zavhan and Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. He started his business in 2002. 

Since then he deposited and saved his earnings in order to buy a small plot of land where he built a house for their family. Before that he used to live in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic housing tent, in someone else's backyard. Also he managed to renew his car twice with profits he earned. 

Now he wants to finish the construction work on his house that has been left to be fixed in the future. He is a hard-working and honest man who says, "I am doing my best to better my family's living conditions." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase construction materials for his house.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials.

loans.name: Genoveva

texts.en:
Genoveva C. is from the village of Dagohoy, Dangcagan, Bukidnon. She is 47 years old. Genoveva is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Genoveva owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, snack foods, beverages, shampoo, soap & biscuits in the local community. Genoveva has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Genoveva joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genoveva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Genoveva is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods & beverages. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Genoveva from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, snack foods & beverages.

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en: Svetlana T. is a widow living in Areg village with her two children, daughter-in-law and two grandchildren. Svetlana works as a housekeeper in the local Culture House. The main income to the family comes from agriculture. Svetlana's older son has left home to work abroad, to make his contribution to his family from there. Svetlana and her younger son work hard to ensure the household's financial stability. They keep livestock and cultivate land. Svetlana is a diligent borrower who has been able to improve her business with the help of a loan from Kiva partner, SEF, in the past. This time Svetlana wants to increase her number of livestock, buy seed to cultivate the land, renovate machinery and buy fuel.

loans.use: to purchase livestock, seeds and fuel and renovate machinery

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old, married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Carmen runs a general store in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for 30 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP per month from these activities.
Carmen joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.
Carmen is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her tenth from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of products such as sugar, vinegar etc.

loans.name: Rida

texts.ar: رضا عمره 48 سنة يعمل في بيع وصناعة الخشب له في عمله 7 سنوات متزوج وله 5 اولاد له في عمله تاريخ جيد فهو محب للعمل مكب عليه يريد ان يطوره وان يزيد من مدخول عائلته وان يتطور نفسه في العمل والمادة يسعى من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى تقوية المصلحة وصيانة عدة العمل يتميز بعمله بالانفراد في منطقته وله زبائن من محيطه واقاربه
texts.en: Rida is 48 years old and works in carpentry. He has worked in this field for seven years. He is married with five children. He has a good history in his business, and he likes his work and is dedicated to it. He would like to develop his business in order to increase the income of his family, and to progress in his work and specialty. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he hopes to benefit from having maintenance done on his tools and equipment. He stands out in his work as he is the only one working in his field in his area. He has customers from his community and from among his relatives.

loans.use: to maintain heavily-used carpentry equipment.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more items for her husband's general store

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene G. is from the village of Nampicuan, Aurora, Isabela. She is 20 years old, married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a specialized retail store selling AVON products such as shampoo, soap and lotion in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2011, Arlene joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Jocelyn Sinarao's Group

texts.en:
Jocelyn S. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. Jocelyn is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Jocelyn is 38 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the food sector selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.ar: محمد عمره 54 سنة متزوج وله 3 اولاد يعمل في بيع اللحم والطعام له في عمله 18 سنة يتميز الدقة والنظافة.وهو متميز كثيرا  حيث انه مقصد لزبائن من محيطه وجيرانه واقاربه يسعى الى تطوير العمل وتحسين وضعه المادي. يريد أن يحسن عيش أولاده. تاريخه جيد مع المجموعة وقد اثر القرض السابق على وضعه المادي والاجتماعي وكان يلقى الدعم المعنوي من عائلته لأنه ساعدهم في تطوير دراستهم. من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة يسعى محمد الى تقوية مصلحته وذلك بشراء لحوم نقداً بأسعار جيدة ليبيعها بأسعار تشجيعية، بالإضافة إلى صيانة صحية منزله. يطمح محمد دائما إلى الاعتماد على ذاته والعيش بشكل جيد.
texts.en: Mohammad is 54 years old and married with three children. He sells meat and other foodstuffs for a living, and he has been working in this field for 18 years. He stands out in his field because of his attention to detail and because of his establishment's cleanliness. He also stands out very much in his area in that he aims to serve customers from his community and from among his neighbors and relatives. He is doing what he can to develop his business and to improve his material position. He wants the best life possible for his children. His has a good history with al-Majmoua, and his previous loan from al-Majmoua positively affected his material circumstances and social standing. He also received the support of his family during his last loan as the loan helped his family members to progress in their studies. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he would like to benefit himself and his family by maintaining the plumbing in his house, and also reinvest in stock for his business (meat), since he continually aspires to be self-reliant and to lead a good life.

loans.use: To Buy meat  with good price and invest in plumbing for his home

loans.name: Sinuern

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinuern S. is 50 years old and her husband, Mr. Sokea Sue, is 49 years old (pictured together). They have been married since 1984 and have three children – two sons and one young daughter. One of the children is a construction worker, one is a garment factory worker and the other attends school. The family lives along National Road Number 2, approximately 13 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.
Sinuern is a farmer while her husband is a taxi driver. Unhappily, a part of his van is old and does not work well. This has upset his business. Therefore, Sinuern is asking for a loan of $1,200 to help her husband to repair the van and change the broken part.

loans.use: to repair her husband's van and change the broken part

loans.name: Juliet Natalaray Group

texts.en:
Juliet N. is from the village of Libertad Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is the group leader of this three-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group members if they are delinquent or default.
Juliet is 23 years old, widowed and has one infant-aged child. She owns and operates a retail store, selling dried goods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month.
In August 2010, Juliet joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Juliet is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new products to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase dry goods for her retail store

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria B. is from the village of Magalalag, East Enrile, Cagayan. She is 51 years old, married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, Maria owns and operates a business venture in the food sector preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2005, Maria joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Maria is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 13th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ron

texts.en:
Mr. Ron M. (pictured here) is 61 years old and his wife, Mrs. Yeun Hin, is 52 years old. They live along National Road Number 6, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1980 and have eight children – four sons and four daughters. Four of the children are married and live outside the family home, three are garment factory workers and the other attends school.
Mr. Ron M. is a fisherman, while his wife is a lotus farmer. He is asking for a loan of $600 to purchase additional fishing nets for his fishing business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing nets

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela is 60 years old and married with 10 children. One child is in school. Marcela works very hard to provide for them.

Marcela runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her general store.

Marcela has been in this business for 12 years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, shampoo, egg, bread, oil, vinegar etc. 

In the future, Marcela would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy items for her general store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rakan

texts.ar: ركان في عمر 62 سنة يعمل في بيع الطعام والمواد الغذائية والمعلبات وغيره له في عمله 19 سنة متزوج وله 4 اولاد يعمل بكد ونشاط محب للعمل يطور عمله باستمرار يريد ان يزيد من مدخول عائلته وتطويرهم ماديا واجتماعيا يتميز عمله بوجود جميع متطلبات منطقته يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى تقوية المصلحة وشراء بضاعة جديدة للمتجر يواجه صعوب فقط في راس المال وهذا ما ينقصه ليتطور
texts.en: Rakan is 62 years old and works selling foods, groceries and canned food items, etc. He has 19 years of experience in his work. He is married and has four children. He works very hard and likes to work. He continually strives to develop his business. He would like to increase the income of his family, and to improve their material situation and social status. His business stands out from others because he offers all of the needed items in his region. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he would like to buy new goods for his store. The only difficulty he faces in his business is a lack of capital, and this is what hinders him from developing his business.

loans.use: to obtain new goods for his grocery store.

loans.name: Phy

texts.en:
Phy S., age 26, is a good and caring father to his lovely young child. He lives in the province of Siem Reap and works as a local fisherman. He always goes to fish in and around Tunle Sap River. After fishing, Phy S. and his wife take their fresh fish to sell at the local market in order to earn their daily income. They have been running this business for many years and have done so with great success.
Phy S. is currently very busy with his business activities because there is an increasing number of customers wanting to buy the fish he sells. To please his customers, Phy S. is asking for a loan to buy additional fishing tools. With the remainder of the loan he will buy different types of fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing tools and different types of fish to sell

loans.name: Jaafar

texts.ar: جعفر عمره 39 سنة متزوج وله ولد يعمل في بيع الدجاج له في عمله 15 سنة له تاريخ جيد في عمله وهو يتميز بحسن معاملة زبائنه وأسعاره المشجعة، معظم زبائنة هم من محيطه وجيرانه بالإضافةأصدقاء ومارين. يواجه بعض الصعوبات المادية في عمله التي تحول دون تطوره يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى تقوية المصلحة وشراء عدة جديدة مثال نتافة الدجاج ، وهي تستخدم لنتف الريش عن الدجاج بطريقة سريعة، وأشياء ضرورية أخرى. يطمح بأن يصبح صاحب مطعم كبير ولكن ما يحول دون تحقيق حلمه هو وضعة الإقتصادي، فهو طموح وجدي في طلب التطور.
texts.en: Jaafar is 39 years old and married with one child. He works selling chicken. He has 15 years of experience in this line of work. He has a good history in his business, as he is distinguished by his attention to detail and by the cleanliness of his store. He has customers from his community and from among his neighbors, all of whom are residents of his region. He faces some material difficulties in his work which prevent him from developing his business. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he would like to improve his situation through the purchase of new equipment. He has ambitions to own a big restaurant, but what stands in the way of him realizing his dream are material concerns. He is ambitious, just as he is serious in his pursuit of development.

loans.use: To Buy an improved machine that takes off chicken Feathers and other useful machines necessary to his business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to pay other women whom she wants to hire in her business

loans.name: Flordeluna

texts.en:
Flordeluna is 30 years old and married with three children who are all in school. Flordeluna works very hard to provide for them.

Flordeluna runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like canned goods, soaps, sugar, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

Flordeluna has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as rice, sugar, soap, sardines etc.. 

In the future, Flordeluna would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chicken feed as well as a machine to grind the feed.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy all the materials she needs in her business

loans.name: Maura

texts.en:
Maura works hard to support her family. Maura is married and has a crab and fish vending business in the Philippines.

Maura requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy crabs and fish to sell.

Maura has been in this business for 25 years now.

In the future, Maura would like to save money to expand her business. The photo was taken after the center meeting. Only the crab is shown  because her fish already sold out early in the morning.

loans.use: to buy additional crabs and fish to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.en:
Rogelia S. is from the village of Naga, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 56  years old and has no children. 

To make a living, Rogelia sells snacks in the local community. Rogelia has been engaged in her business for two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. 

Rogelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business

Rogelia is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional raw ingredients and for working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Rogelia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for snack  vending

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar: علي عمره 39 سنة متزوج وله 7 اولاد يعمل كمزارع ومربي للمواشي وبيع الحليب واللحم له في عمله 20 سنة يحب عمله ويتميز به بالدقة والنظافة يمتلك عدد جيد من المواشي لكنه يواجه صعوبة بتأمين العلف لهم وصيانة المزرعة يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء اعلاف للمواشي + اكنة للعلف لا يواجه صعوبات في المنافسة لكنه يريد ان يطور عمله ويطمح بشراء عدد اكبر من المواشي وتأمين المكان الجيد لهم
texts.en: Ali is 39 years old and married with seven children. He works as a farmer and raises livestock, as well as sells milk and meat. He has 20 years of experience in his work. He likes his work, and he stands out in his field of work through his attention to detail and cleanliness. He owns a good number of livestock, though he is facing difficulties in procuring feed for them, just as he is facing difficulties in keeping up his farm. With a loan from al-Majmoua, he would like to buy feed for his livestock as well as a machine for the feed. Competition does not pose a problem for him, but he wishes to develop his business. His ambitions are to buy more livestock and to secure a good place for them.

loans.use: to purchase feed for his livestock and machinery for his farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizers and mulch for his farm.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna R. is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old, married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Myrna runs a general store in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for five years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. 

Myrna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Myrna is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Myrna from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase products for her general store

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice, 33 years old and married with one child, has been selling clothes for four years, working hard in her business to support her family. Through business training offered by Faulu Kenya, she has learnt how to manage her business and hopes to expand her business in order to become financially stable in the future.  Alice has requested 20,000 Kes to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes for her business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
As a widowed parent of 4 children, Rosita works hard to support her family. She has a fish vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Rosita is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to sell.

Rosita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 17 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of starting an additional business and expanding the existing one.

loans.use: to buy more fish

loans.name: Cecelia

texts.en:
Cecelia works hard to support her family. Cecelia is single and has a rice retailing business in the Philippines.
Cecelia is borrowing PHP 3500 through NWTF to buy a solar lamp.She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have backup light in case of emergency. Cecelia is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is saving money, she helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: To pay for the purchase of solar lamp

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy computers

loans.name: Jesusa

texts.en:
As a married parent of 3 children, Jesusa works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from direct selling of cosmetics. Jesusa is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to buy items to sell like biscuits, juices, etc to sell in her food vending business.

Jesusa has been sustaining her business activities through her past 8 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: To buy items to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael, a 39-year-old married father of two children in school, has been selling clothes for the past 10 years to earn a living.  He has two employees. Michael also sells music discs and tapes to earn extra income and hopes to expand his business to become financially stable in the future.  With the loan of 50,000 kes, he will buy a loudspeaker, amplifier and generator.

loans.use: to buy a loudspeaker, amplifier and a generator.

loans.name: Rosalina Frilles' Group

texts.en:
Rosalina F., from the village of Santa Tumauini, Isabela, is the 59-year-old leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each group member receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosalina F.' Group.

Rosalina, who is married and has three grown children, owns and operates a bakery selling bread to the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional cooking ingredients, she is requesting her 12th loan of 15000 PHP for the same purpose. Rosalina plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her bakery.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional cooking ingredients

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel is 31 years old and married with two children.  He sells charcoal ("makaa") to earn a living for his family.  He has been running the business for eleven years and he has employed one person.  Through Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business hence improving his living standards.  He has requested 40,000 Kes to add to his stock of charcoal.

loans.use: To add to his stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 36-year-old man, married and father of three, who works in the clothing business. He lives in Bint Jbeil and has eight years of experience. His sells clothes by traveling with his van between villages. Ali is committed to his work and loyal to his clients. 

This Ali's third loan. He reports that the previous loans helped him increase his income. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase his capital. In the future, he wishes to expand his business and start selling wholesale.

loans.use: To buy new spring and summer collection in good prices

loans.name: Kalyskan Group

texts.en:
"Kalyskan” is a group from Chonkara village which is situated at the southern part of Kyrgyzstan.  All members of the group are engaged in cattle breeding and land cultivation. 

Kalyskan A. is the leader of the group. She is 55, married, and has eight children. She started her business with the initial capital of 5.000 KGS and managed to develop a farm with five milch cows and sheep. Also, her family is engaged in cultivating rice, which allows them to earn the sum of 4.000 KGS in a month. 

Members of the “Kalyskan” group have applied for a loan of 54.000 KGS to purchase cattle and fertilizers to manure their land. This will allow them to get a good harvest of rice and raise their sales of milk and meat products. In future, they plan to broaden their businesses. 
 
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open another outlet of his business.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a 29-year-old member of Imani group under Faulu Kenya.  She has been operating a boutique so as to earn a living.  She has employed one person in the business.  Even though she runs her business in a competitive environment, she is able to retain her clients because of her good customer care.  

Eunice is determined to expand her business and open other outlets in the future.  She has requested a loan of 50,000 Kes to buy belts and clothes.

loans.use: To buy belts and clothes for resale.

loans.name: Shinehuu

texts.en:
Shinehuu is 40 years old and lives with her mother and daughter, 14, in their own apartment in the Sansar area of Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her daughter, Nomin-Erdene, goes to a secondary school. 

Shinehuu operated a bakery shop and goods trading business in 1996. With years of business earnings, she managed to start her grocery trading business in 2007, near to her home. She owns the shop where she sells a wide collection of products such as bread, biscuits, candies and some other grocery items. However she rented her grocery store to someone else due to her bad health condition in 2009.  

Now she wants to operate her grocery store again. She says that her business was quite profitable because of the good location of her store. Her store is located between apartments and schools. She is a very polite and diligent person who wants to continue her business in the future. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase products for her grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle and repair her old house.

loans.name: Matin

texts.en:
Matin was born in 1975.  He is a married man with three children.  He was introduced to Uhuru Harvesters group in Faulu Kenya.  He has been able to sustain his furniture-making business through the group.  This is because the group members share business ideas, save their money, and guarantee each other's business loans.  

Matin has requested 20,000 Kes to buy lumber and renovate his business premises. Matin aspires to own a piece of land where he can build his home in the future.

loans.use: To buy lumber and renovate his business premises.

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en:
Angeline is a 43 year old widow with 4 children.  With 1 child  in school, Angeline works very hard to provide for them.

Angeline runs a feed retailing business in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of feed to sell.

Angeline has been in this business for 1 year and sells a variety of items such as hog and fish feed. 

In the future Angeline would like to save money to expand her business and send her child to college.

loans.use: To buy additional sacks of feeds to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan is a 57-year-old man, married and father of one, who works in the transportation sector. He lives in Bint Jbeil and has 32 years of experience. He is very committed and hard-working. He transports  water and plows to cultivate land.

This is Adnan's fourth loan. He reports that the previous ones helped him increase his income. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy a plowing machine. In the future, he wishes to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy a plowing machine.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 67 years old and married with 10 children.

Anita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a Sari-sari Store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 15000 loan through NWTF to buy additional stock for her general store.

Anita has borrowed and repaid 26 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the Sari-sari Store for 6 years and also earns an income from a door to door cosmetic business.

Anita aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her sari-sari store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Teshigsuren

texts.en:
Teshigsuren is 35 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in a house in Zavhan province of Mongolia. His older daughter, age 10, attends secondary school while his younger daughter, age 5, goes to kindergarten. 

Teshigsuren and his wife conduct a clothing trading business in the center of Zavhan province. Even though they have been managing their business for seven months they have learned a lot during this short time period and customers are satisfied with the quality and reasonable price of their products. 

They used to live in the countryside and herd animals, but after their older daughter began to attend school they decided to move to the center of Zavhan province in order to make it easier for their daughter. Now they want to continue their business and to build a strong customer base in the future. They are very hard-working and polite people who say, "All we want is a bright future for our daughters, so we work hard to provide all the necessities they wish to have." Teshigsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory for his clothing trading store.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Kombo

texts.en: Kombo, a 38-year-old married father of two children, has been operating a cafeteria for the past two years. Since he runs the business in a slum area, most of his customers are low-income earners. Kombo also earns extra income from his rental houses, and he previously sold second-hand clothes. Now requesting 20,000 Kes to expand his cafeteria premises, he hopes to open a big hotel in five years.

loans.use: to expand his cafeteria premises

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy D. is from the village of Nampicuan. She is 38 years old. Joy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Joy owns and operates a gasoline station in the local community. Joy has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Joy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Joy is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional gasoline to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Joy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional gasoline to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase a new carpet-weaving frame and other important materials

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius O. M. is 39 years old and single. 

He has been running an electric supply shop for 11 years. He was previously working as an electrician. 

He joined Faulu Kenya so that he could easily save his money and access a loan easily. He has requested 20,000 KES, which he will use to buy electrical appliances such as multi-plug sockets, switches and electrical cables. 

He hopes to fully establish his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy multi-plug sockets, switches and electrical cables

loans.name: Dzingenhamo Group

texts.en:
Florence D., in the middle of the front row, is the leader of the Dzingenhamo group. Florence is a 48-year-old cross-border trader who imports blankets, clothes and pots for resale.  Her husband works as a driver at a local firm. They have 4 children and two other dependants. One child aged 15 is still attending school. Her business operations at times dwindle as a result of her debtors failing to pay on time. 

Florence will buy more clothing and blankets for resale with the loan she has requested through MicroKing. She will also purchase airtime cards for resale. She strongly believes that her livelihood will be improved by the loan as she sees herself acquiring better household assets. Florence wishes to own her business premises in the future as she is currently renting. She is very thankful to MicroKing and Kiva for the loan facility that will assist in increasing her productivity.

loans.use: to buy more blankets and clothes for resale

loans.name: Nansaljav

texts.en:
Nansaljav N. is 44 years old and lives by himself in a ger, a Mongolian traditional housing tent, in the Uvs province of Mongolia. 

He manages a Mongolian traditional shoe-making business with the help of his relative. 

He started his business in 2005. He makes four or five pairs of shoes per day and sells them at a local market. Customers are very satisfied with the quality and design of his goods. 

His business is quite profitable during the fall, winter and spring period. Now his working capital exceeds 500,000 MNT. He is planning to expand his business in the future. 

Besides his shoe-making business he works as a plumber during summer and gets paid 300,000 to 500,000 MNT of monthly salary. 

He is a hardworking man who says, "I would like to get married in near future." 

He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan to purchase fabrics and materials for his business.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 26-year-old single man, working as a furniture maker. He lives in Bint Jbeil and has eight years of experience. He is committed to his work and is honest, energetic and hardworking.
 
This is Ali's third loan. He reports that the previous ones helped improve his business. He is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy a generator. 

In the future, he wishes to expand his business and start a beautiful family.

loans.use: to buy a generator

loans.name: Hajidmaa

texts.en:
Hajidmaa P. is a 41-year-old widow who lives with her son, Batzaya, in their own house in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. Her husband died in 2007. 

She manages a goods-trading business in her town. She started her business in 2000 with working capital of 350,000 MNT. With 11 years of stable business operation she gained much experience and expanded her business. She travels to China once or twice a month in order to import her goods. 

Recently she opened a hair salon in her town. She built a strong customer base and customers are happy with her polite and quick service. Now her working capital has reached 2,800,000 MNT. 

She is a polite woman who says."Being polite is number one importance for business success." 

She is requesting a 2,100,000 MNT loan to purchase a collection of goods from China.

loans.use: to purchase a collection of goods from China

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
Maria Elena P. is from the village of Nampicuan. She is 30 years old. Maria Elena is married and has one school-aged child. 

To make a living, Maria Elena sells mobile electronic and prepaid card loads in the local community. Maria Elena has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Maria Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Maria Elena is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional mobile loads to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Maria Elena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional mobile loads to sell

loans.name: Sharavdorj

texts.en:
Sharavdorj S. is 41 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in a house in the Zavhan province of Mongolia. 

His wife is an officer at the tax department of Zavhan province. His two daughters, age 8 and 14, both attend secondary school. 

Sharavdorj manages an animal rawhides-trading business between the center of Zavhan province and his town. He started his business in 1998. Since then his business has been quite successful and that allowed him to expand it not only in the center of Zavhan province but also in the capital city of Mongolia. 

With his business earnings, he had a chance to renew his car and to build a house that they live in today. 

During years of business operation he gained much experience and developed good communications with his partners. He is an honest man who says, "I am trying hard to better the living condition of my family." 

He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more animal rawhides from local residents in his town.

loans.use: to purchase animal rawhides

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to build up his business and buy a big shop for his business.

loans.name: Urjinhand

texts.en:
Urjinhand is 33 years old and lives with her husband and 5-year-old son in a house in the Sansar area in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. Her husband is a director of his own construction company and her son, who hasn't reached school-age yet, stays home. 

Urjinhand manages a clothing trading business out of a rented stall in Bayanzurh market, one of the most crowded markets in Ulaanbaatar city. She started her business in 2010 after working as a cook and salesperson in someone else's store. Now she sells collections of clothing such as bags, lingerie, shoes and clothes, etc. 

Urjinhand travels to Erlian, a border city in China, three or four times a month in order to import her goods. Her business has been quite profitable which allowed her to buy a minibus to transport the goods she bought. She is an honest and polite woman with lots of good personality. She says,"I want to import more and more goods before customs taxes get higher in 2011." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more clothes from Erlian.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes.

loans.name: Yeson-Erdene

texts.en:
Yeson-Erdene is a married woman, age 39, who lives with her husband and two children in a house in Tuv province, Mongolia. Her husband is a herdsman with a total of 70 husbandry animals. Her two children, ages 4 and 6, both attend kindergarten. She operates a grocery store in her town. 

At first she used to rent a small booth where she sold a variety of grocery items. She started her grocery trading business in 2000. With 11 years of business experience, she has managed to expand her business into a medium-sized grocery store. Her business success is due to the good location of her store which is placed between residential apartments and schools. She is a diligent woman who wants to expand her grocery store into a supermarket. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more grocery items for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items.

loans.name: Wisdom Group

texts.en:
Fortunate P. is the group leader of Wisdom Group. She is a young lady aged 29 and can be identified in the group picture in a pink blouse. She is a widow with two children aged 8 and 4. She also has one dependant that she cares for. She has three years experience of home decor and kitchenware sales.  

She sells her kitchenware to local individuals and companies. She also runs a poultry business that supplements her income. The challenge she faces in her business is losses emanating from breakages, as most of her kitchenware is  breakable. 

With the loan, she intends to increase her stocks to enable her to deliver her orders on time. The profits from the business will cover her family’s general upkeep and assist on school fees for her children.  Her dream is to diversify her business by opening up a salon.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of kitchenware for resale

loans.name: Nem

texts.en:
Nem H. is a 22-year-old married father who makes a living by selling firewood in the province of Kompong Tom. He doesn’t have a life partner because he got divorced from his wife years ago. 

Nem H. currently lives with his sister who is feeding some pigs in her pigpen for a profit. There are two children who need him to take care of them because they are so young; one of them is studying in the local school. 

Nem H. will use his loan to buy additional pigs for breeding purposes. This could make his family extra income, and he will sell them off when the pigs are big enough. In the future, he wants to expand his business and construct a new house.

loans.use: To buy additional pigs for breeding purposes.

loans.name: Ridwan

texts.en:
Ridwan is a 26-year-old man, married and father of one, working in several businesses: furniture, upholstery, tailoring and cars. He is honest, wants to improve his business, and has a good reputation. 

This is Ridwan's third loan. He reports that the previous ones helped him support his family's needs, financially and socially. He is requesting a loan with Al Majmoua in order to buy necessary materials for his business such as textiles and accessories. 

In the future, he wishes to expand his business and buy modern tools and machinery.

loans.use: To buy textiles and accessories.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy all the goods he needs in his general store.

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
Nazira K., 31, is the leader of this group. Unlike the other members of her team, who have several years of experience in business, Nazira is a beginner in agricultural work. Though she is a fragile woman and a mother of two boys, her job calls for extremely tough physical pressure that usually males deal with. 

Being a transporter in a cement mill  takes nine hours of Nazira’s precious daytime, which she could have spent with her dear boys. In fact, Nazira and her spouse are colleagues. It was he who taught Nazira the key to effective driving with a minimum loss of time and fuel. 

Nazira resides in the tiny town of Tup, in Issyk Kul region, with a population of approximately 15,000 people and she knows very well how few employment opportunities there are here. Local traditions, lifestyle and landscape have formed the main activities of this area’s residents – farming and livestock breeding. 

Many successful business stories of her neighbors, colleagues and friends, who are well-trained farmers, escalated Nazira’s wish to engage in farming. She believes that her entrepreneurial skills, land, good climate and a constant desire to learn something new will push the level of the business upward. The only thing she lacks is financial capital. For this reason she gathered a group of ambitious private entrepreneurs like her and applied for a loan from Kiva, cooperating with its field partner in Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance. 

Nazira will start with the purchase of 500 kg of potato seeds. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds.

loans.name: Doer Group

texts.en:
Ronika M. is a widow aged 56. She has 6 children. Two of her children  aged 16 and 20 are still attending school. She also has two other dependents that she takes care of.  She is the one in front on the group picture. 

Ronika sells traditional foods like madora (Mopane worms), matemba (small dried fish), peanut butter, small grains, and vegetables.  She has been operating her small business for the past 28 years. She buys her stocks from Binga and Gwanda. Fluctuations in transport costs negatively affect her business.

Ronika has requested this loan from MicroKing for the purpose of increasing her stocks. She believes that with access to microcredit, her income will increase resulting in improved diet and general welfare. She is also planning on expanding her operations by opening a peanut butter manufacturing company.

loans.use: to buy traditional foods and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Katchakhan's Group

texts.en:
Katchakhan J., 57, is the leader of this group. She followed an example of many generations of women in her family and built a big family. Katchakhan is the mother of six children, the youngest of whom is twenty. She is very proud of this fact and considers it the most important accomplishment in her long life. 

Katchakhan and her spouse, a journalist in a local editing house “Uzgen Nuru” (“The Ray of Uzgen”), live on their own in the small sunny town of Uzgen, in the Southern Kyrgyzstan. While her husband is busy writing and editing articles, Katchakhan takes care of a big herd of livestock, which she started breeding right after marriage thirty-two years ago. 

An initial capital of 15 000 soms plus Katchakhan’s physical labor and affordable costs helped to advance the business, so that it generates 5 000 soms monthly. She motivated and organized this group of creative entrepreneurs and plans to spend her portion of the loan on buying six head of sheep for further breeding and reselling. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Ibrahim Kalil

texts.fr:
Monsieur Ibrahim Kalil Sidibé est âgée de 33  ans, marié et  père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants au  quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école   pour des raisons sociales, il commença très tôt à faire le commerce de parures auprès  de sa grande sœur qui 
menait des activités commerciales au marché de Médine. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à son côté, il commence à évoluer seul pour faire le commerce d’articles divers et cela depuis 10 ans  et  jouit d’une grande expérience dans ce domaine. 
Dans le souci de toujours mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il sollicite ce deuxième prêt, le premier ayant été correctement remboursé. Il est en relation avec  Soro Yiriwaso,  depuis 12 mois.  Il compte utiliser ce deuxième prêt pour acheter, 10 complets de chaînes et 2 douzaines de tasses inoxydables. Il  s’approvisionne sur place.
Monsieur Ibrahim Kalil Sidibé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes parmi ses clients figurent quelques hommes.
Ainsi avec ce prêt il envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA, ce qui lui permettra de rembourser son prêt et de continuer son activité.  
Son ambition est de pérenniser son activité et d’avoir plus de financement.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibrahim Kalil Sidibé is 33 years old, married and father to two children. He lives with his wife and children in the Medine district of the town of Ségou (the Republic of Mali's fourth administrative region).

Since he did not attend school, for social reasons, he began selling sets of jewelry with his elder sister who carried out her trading activities at the market in Médine. After several years' apprenticeship with her, he began to develop his own business selling various items and has been doing this now for ten years, thus benefiting from significant experience in this field. 

With the intention of satisfying his ever growing customer base even more, he is requesting this second loan, the first having been repaid in full. He has been working with Soro Yiriwaso for the past twelve months. He is planning to use this second loan to buy ten chain sets and two dozen stainless steel cups. He gets his supplies locally.

Mr. Sidibé sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up principally of women although he does have some male customers. 

With this loan he is expecting to make a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA, which will allow him to repay his loan and to continue his business. His ambition is to maintain his business in the long term and to be able to access more funding.

loans.use: to purchase various items

loans.name: Kalbubu's Group

texts.en:
Kalbubu E., 60, is the leader of this group. She resides in Uzgen and several years ago became a widow, left with three children. Her children are in their twenties, but the great tragedy for the whole family is the oldest daughter’s physical disability. She is 29, but still needs constant care and the attention of doctors. 

Kalbubu’s younger kids assist her financially. Her daughter is in Russia and the son runs a business in farming. For thirty-eight years now, Kalbubu has designed national clothing, souvenirs and national hats called “tumak”. The business was run successfully for more than three decades thanks to growing interest of local and foreign customers. 

Growing older Kalbubu keeps feeling less good and was forced to quit working so hard and to devote some time to herself. A few years ago she was lucky to have good medical treatment in the neighboring country of Turkmenistan. Unfortunately, it’s not a cheap procedure, so in order to get another medical treatment she is requesting a loan from Kiva. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for medical treatment.

loans.name: Fotemogoban Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe FOTEMOGOBAN sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36  ans, et  en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Banconi, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali.) 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt  de groupe avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
MAYAMA KADIATOU D. fait le commerce de bois de chauffe dans ce groupe de femmes FOTEMOGOBAN. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 5 chargements de charrette d’âne en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants de la ville de Sikasso.  Elle les revend dans son  quartiers  Banconi,  sur commande et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.500FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The four members the FOTEMOGOBAN group are married women who average 36 years of age and four children each. They live mainly in polygamous families in Banconi, a popular neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali.)

This is their seventh group loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to meet the needs of their customers. All previous loans were correctly repaid.

MAYAMA KADIATOU D. is a member of the FOTEMOGOBAN group who sells firewood. With her loan, she plans to buy five donkey cartloads of firewood. She gets her stock in the villages surrounding Sikasso. She conducts her sales in her neighborhood of Banconi, on order and from her home, for cash, to a clientele composed of both men and women.

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 27,500 FCFA, which will be used to pay the loan and its interest, and to boost her savings.

Her goal is to increase her sales and better satisfy her customers.

loans.use: to buy firewood for resale

loans.name: Mastura's Group

texts.en:
Mastura Z., 62, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of the town Kadamjai, known for its stibium plant, exporting its goods to all parts of the country and to neighboring nations. Mastura’s husband works in that plant, while she has been breeding and reselling livestock animals for forty-one years now. 

Her kids are grown and live independently, so she devotes her entire time to promoting her business. The initial capital was only 500 soms, but Mastura believes that the main reason for success in business is commitment and full devotion. Her secret formula of success has worked out well and now her business brings 3 000 soms monthly. The purpose of Mastura’s loan is the purchase of five sheep. As the leader of the group, Mastura promises to control and motivate the entire group to work hard for the sake of family prosperity and successful repayment of the loan.

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase five sheep.

loans.name: Kotognogontala. Group

texts.fr:
KOTOGNOGONTALA est un groupe constitué de 4 femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne  36  ans, 4 enfants et qui vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
AWA C. est la vendeuse d’habits de ce groupe de femmes KOTOGNOGONTALA. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt une cinquantaine de mètre de bazin. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Elle les revend de façon ambulante dans les différents quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, sur commande et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.000FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et  pour épargne.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Kotognogontala is a group of four married women, who are in average 36 years old, have four children and mostly live in polygamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.
They are requesting their fifth loan from the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to improve their business. The previous loans were fully repaid. Awa C. is a member of the group and she sells clothes.
With her loan she wants to buy fifty meters of damask. She purchases her supplies at the big market of Sikasso and she sells them door to door in the different neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso, to a clientele composed of men and women and she accepts only cash payments.
She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 27.000 FCFA, part of which will be used to pay back the loan and invested in savings.
She aims to improve her business to better satisfy her customers

loans.use: to purchase damask

loans.name: Gulbaara's Group

texts.en:
Gulbaara D., 56, is the leader of this group. She is a widow. All of her kids are abroad except her youngest son, who is a college student. 

Gulbaara has been a librarian for a long period of time. Aaside from that she also owns a rich household of a cow with a calf, six heads of sheep and goats. Her business was started with the breeding of one calf by Gulbaara’s mother-in-law. Gulbaara has worked hard to keep the business running and it has paid her back by allowing the family income to cover the major repair costs of the house. The monthly income is 3,000 soms. With the loan from Kiva, she plans to buy poultry and start the retail sale of eggs. Gulbaara’s dream is to build a poultry farm. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Green Machine Group

texts.en:
Rosemary M. (pictured in red) is a cross-border trader. She is 49, a widow, and has three children who are no longer going to school. She has one dependent whom she also takes care of.  Her additional income comes from her late husband’s pension that she receives from the Zimbabwe National Army. She faces difficulties in acquiring sufficient funds for bulky purchases.
